Full Page Text: ANGELA HEAPS View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-043db812eb1b49b9809f .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-043db812eb1b49b9809f .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } Angela Heaps is an artist currently residing in Philadelphia. They work primarily with prints on paper and sculptures made out of paper pulp to personify verbal and non-verbal gestures. Their work is influenced by everyday objects, obsessions and bad humor. They often finds Themselves indulging in impulses and tends to remember shitty times fondly.  Angela received their BFA from Maryland Institute College of Art in 2015.
Description:
Angela Heaps is an artist currently residing in Philadelphia. They work primarily with prints on paper and sculptures made out of paper pulp to personify verbal and non-verbal gestures. Their work is influenced by everyday objects, obsessions and bad humor. 

They often finds Themselves indulging in impulses and tends to remember shitty times fondly. 

 

Angela received their BFA from Maryland Institute College of Art in 2015.

Full Page Text:
GRACE BERMAN

Grace Berman is an artist living and working in Philadelphia. She currently uses a variety of ceramic techniques to create functional work. She is inspired by wandering through the city with her eyes partially glued to her phone and repetitive domestic anxieties. In decorative motifs she  strives to nail down representations of a vague memory soup.




Grace received her BFA in Craft and Material Studies from Virginia Commonwealth University in 2017

CHRISTOPHER RICHARDSChristopher Richards is an artist based in Philadelphia, PA. His range of adoptive methods includes painting, producing sculptures, printing photographs, dancing, making noises, and growing mushrooms. His work is a practice of repetitions and reversals, it’s all about analogy, mysticism, and chiasmus. When you take time to appreciate an artwork, it takes the same time and appreciates you. www.christopherrichardsart.com #block-yui_3_17_2_1_1594837327201_27120 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -11px; } #block-yui_3_17_2_1_1594837327201_27120 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 11px; margin-bottom: 11px; }

Amanda Schneider View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-yui_3_17_2_1_1550018835247_3866 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-yui_3_17_2_1_1550018835247_3866 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } Amanda Schneider is an artist based in Philadelphia working primarily with ceramics. Her work is concerned with the study and reinterpretation of ceramic history and with thinking about objects as companions. Most of her work is influenced by Greek Attic pottery painting and to some degree, camp aesthetics. Amanda studied at the University of Kansas where she received her B.F.A. in Ceramics in 2014.
Description: Amanda Schneider is an artist based in Philadelphia working primarily with ceramics. Her work is concerned with the study and reinterpretation of ceramic history and with thinking about objects as companions. Most of her work is influenced by Greek Attic pottery painting and to some degree, camp aesthetics. Amanda studied at the University of Kansas where she received her B.F.A. in Ceramics in 2014.

Full Page Text: HENRY GEPFER

SARAH TRAD View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-cdc7997bf07bff4c2f0d .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-cdc7997bf07bff4c2f0d .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } Sarah is a video artist whose work explores the relationship between subjective and objective emotionality, navigating daily life and relationships while faced with mental illness, and breaking down stereotypes of gender and narrative. The living embodiment of the correlation between chronic depression and binge watching practices, her work consists of appropriating and manipulating found footage from movies, music videos and television. She also likes to use text, performance and elements of karaoke (which she is obsessed with but has never actually performed IRL) to create recognizable narrative structures that can be viewed in and outside the academy of art. Sarah studied at the Film and Television School of Performing Arts (FAMU) in Prague and received her BFA from Syracuse University.
Description:
Sarah is a video artist whose work explores the relationship between subjective and objective emotionality, navigating daily life and relationships while faced with mental illness, and breaking down stereotypes of gender and narrative. The living embodiment of the correlation between chronic depression and binge watching practices, her work consists of appropriating and manipulating found footage from movies, music videos and television. She also likes to use text, performance and elements of karaoke (which she is obsessed with but has never actually performed IRL) to create recognizable narrative structures that can be viewed in and outside the academy of art.

 

Sarah studied at the Film and Television School of Performing Arts (FAMU) in Prague and received her BFA from Syracuse University.

Full Page Text: CAYLA LOCKWOOD View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-de51258e33ffe0671d76 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-de51258e33ffe0671d76 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } caylalockwood.comCayla Lockwood makes things with words. She is interested in small gestures, complicated feelings, and saying a lot with a little. She works in a variety of media from broken glass to gel pens and in formats including drawing, collage and installation. Her favorite emotion is ‘funny but sad'. Cayla comes from a small town in the thumb of Michigan, has an MFA from Syracuse University, and was Artist-in-Residence at Artspace New Haven. She is currently an artist-in-residence at Flux Factory in Queens, NY. Past Exhibitions:October 2017: Baker's DozenMay 2018: (Re)mnantsJuly 2018: Sincerely Yours
Description:

Full Page Text: #block-yui_3_17_2_1_1550021364195_4085 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -20px; } #block-yui_3_17_2_1_1550021364195_4085 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 20px; margin-bottom: 20px; } SIYUAN LIUsiyuanliuart.comThis body of work references political propaganda posters. The portrait of the Chinese leader Mao Zedong is a deep collective memory of every single Chinese citizen. We’ve have been taught to be a patriot since our birth. Just like the rock song said we are the balls/eggs under the red flag. Currently, in China and especially in some undeveloped areas, the figure of Mao has still consecrated a god-- a savior of people. Chinese left-wing politicians and scholars still promote propaganda if his ideologies in print images both in poster form and on the internet. In contrast, in the capitalist world, Mao is considered as an evil dictator and tyrant. In my opinion, we should provide an objective definition of this figure instead of the extremely biased read from history. I have chosen his portrait because it is symbolic, powerful, controversial, and it contains complex meanings.The draperies and cloths have three meanings for me. First, it is an important memory of my childhood. When I started to draw and sketch at the age of six, the lights and shades of the drapery were difficult to render because fabric folds are soft, changing, and the shading complicated. I admired the western masters since they could paint the draperies and cloths realistically. Depicting fabric is important to me because the material holds the cultural and historical reference. The invention of fabric is a significant symbol if civilization. Human beings use the cloth to protect themselves from the hostile environment and extreme weather, as well as to cover their private body parts which means the social structure tended to stable because of the sense of proprietorship of sex. Lastly, the father of Chinese rock and roll Cui Jian wrote a famous song “ A Piece of Red Cloth” in 1988. This song describes his struggle in a romantic relationship. However, there are many political metaphors underneath such as the first lyrics that day you used a piece of red cloth to cover my eyes and the sky. The red cloth can be considered as the color of the communist party and the Chinese flag. This song connected romantic love and political realities together to create an unusual and ambiguous atmosphere. Furthermore, the fear of the authority, as well as the implicit expression of feelings, the metaphor is the most important part in Chinese literature in history.In the series titled Protection, I cut draperies and cloth pieces from my collection of western master painting books to cover Mao’s portrait with multiple compositions. Then, I utilized Photoshop to adjust the color tone. The final step is to print multiple large posters like images using a high-quality fine art printer. In the series of work, I redefine the meaning of the process of collage as a method instead of a result because the printed posters contain the meaning of mechanical reproductions and delivering the message which is the political propaganda in modern history. The ambiguity is also an important aspect of my work. The defacing of Mao could be considered an insult or a criticism. On closer inspection, the viewer will see that the thick paint across the image is actually drapery and cloth, and the meaning of protection emerges. Lastly, another layer of ambiguity is that am I preventing the viewer from seeing Mao’s face, and simultaneously, blocking Mao’s gaze at us?
Description:
This body of work references political propaganda posters. The portrait of the Chinese leader Mao Zedong is a deep collective memory of every single Chinese citizen. We’ve have been taught to be a patriot since our birth. Just like the rock song said we are the balls/eggs under the red flag. Currently, in China and especially in some undeveloped areas, the figure of Mao has still consecrated a god-- a savior of people. Chinese left-wing politicians and scholars still promote propaganda if his ideologies in print images both in poster form and on the internet. In contrast, in the capitalist world, Mao is considered as an evil dictator and tyrant. In my opinion, we should provide an objective definition of this figure instead of the extremely biased read from history. I have chosen his portrait because it is symbolic, powerful, controversial, and it contains complex meanings.

The draperies and cloths have three meanings for me. First, it is an important memory of my childhood. When I started to draw and sketch at the age of six, the lights and shades of the drapery were difficult to render because fabric folds are soft, changing, and the shading complicated. I admired the western masters since they could paint the draperies and cloths realistically. Depicting fabric is important to me because the material holds the cultural and historical reference. The invention of fabric is a significant symbol if civilization. Human beings use the cloth to protect themselves from the hostile environment and extreme weather, as well as to cover their private body parts which means the social structure tended to stable because of the sense of proprietorship of sex. Lastly, the father of Chinese rock and roll Cui Jian wrote a famous song “ A Piece of Red Cloth” in 1988. This song describes his struggle in a romantic relationship. However, there are many political metaphors underneath such as the first lyrics that day you used a piece of red cloth to cover my eyes and the sky. The red cloth can be considered as the color of the communist party and the Chinese flag. This song connected romantic love and political realities together to create an unusual and ambiguous atmosphere. Furthermore, the fear of the authority, as well as the implicit expression of feelings, the metaphor is the most important part in Chinese literature in history.

In the series titled Protection, I cut draperies and cloth pieces from my collection of western master painting books to cover Mao’s portrait with multiple compositions. Then, I utilized Photoshop to adjust the color tone. The final step is to print multiple large posters like images using a high-quality fine art printer. In the series of work, I redefine the meaning of the process of collage as a method instead of a result because the printed posters contain the meaning of mechanical reproductions and delivering the message which is the political propaganda in modern history. The ambiguity is also an important aspect of my work. The defacing of Mao could be considered an insult or a criticism. On closer inspection, the viewer will see that the thick paint across the image is actually drapery and cloth, and the meaning of protection emerges. Lastly, another layer of ambiguity is that am I preventing the viewer from seeing Mao’s face, and simultaneously, blocking Mao’s gaze at us?

Full Page Text: J. Alex Schechter View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-98fed20273a6c3f94598 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-98fed20273a6c3f94598 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } www.alexschechter.com J. Alex Schechter (b. Moose, WY 1988) is a sculptor, curator and writer based in Philadelphia, PA. His work focuses on the divisions and arbitrary borders between the natural and built world. Much of his work focuses on systems of knowledge and the explorations of geometric and non-linear growth. He received his BA from Grinnell College in 2010 and his MFA from MICA in 2016.
Description: J. Alex Schechter (b. Moose, WY 1988) is a sculptor, curator and writer based in Philadelphia, PA. His work focuses on the divisions and arbitrary borders between the natural and built world. Much of his work focuses on systems of knowledge and the explorations of geometric and non-linear growth. He received his BA from Grinnell College in 2010 and his MFA from MICA in 2016.

Full Page Text: KAYTE TERRY View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-56fe873071f88211d51f .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-56fe873071f88211d51f .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } http://www.kayteterry.com/Kayte Terry’s work examines the literal and figurative boundaries of the body. Through photography, video, collage, installation and object-making, Kayte unravel issues of illness, memory, dysmorphia, longing and loss. The patchwork of materials she uses form a personal language that speaks to the fuzzy intersection of personal desires and cultural expectations.Kayte studied Art History and Women’s Studies at Simon’s Rock College of Bard and is an MFA Candidate for Studio Art at University of the Arts. She has also studied abroad with the School for International Training in Fortaleza, Brazil and at the Santa Reparata International School of Art in Florence, Italy. Kayte has been in group shows in New York, NY; Philadelphia, PA and Seattle, WA and is looking forward to participating in the showAdorned: Beauty in Excess at Joy Pratt Markham Gallery at the Walton Arts Center in Fayetteville, AK this Spring.
Description:
Kayte Terry’s work examines the literal and figurative boundaries of the body. Through photography, video, collage, installation and object-making, Kayte unravel issues of illness, memory, dysmorphia, longing and loss. The patchwork of materials she uses form a personal language that speaks to the fuzzy intersection of personal desires and cultural expectations.

Kayte studied Art History and Women’s Studies at Simon’s Rock College of Bard and is an MFA Candidate for Studio Art at University of the Arts. She has also studied abroad with the School for International Training in Fortaleza, Brazil and at the Santa Reparata International School of Art in Florence, Italy. Kayte has been in group shows in New York, NY; Philadelphia, PA and Seattle, WA and is looking forward to participating in the showAdorned: Beauty in Excess at Joy Pratt Markham Gallery at the Walton Arts Center in Fayetteville, AK this Spring.

Full Page Text:
SARAH O'DONOGHUE

sarahodonoghue.com

Sarah O'Donoghue is a visual artist, curator, and educator based in West Philadelphia. Her work is inspired by mythology, satire, fantasy, and experience. She received her BFA in 2009 from School of Visual Arts in New York City and her MFA in 2017 from American University in Washington DC.

JEREMY SIMS View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-98003075faccf6122c07 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-98003075faccf6122c07 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } www.simsart.workJeremy Sims is an artist, collaborator and educator making work in Philadelphia. He is the Program Coordinator at University City Arts League and in the past has worked with various projects and collectives such as Nobody's Gallery and The Art Locker. In 2012 Jeremy was a resident artist at the Guldagergaard International Ceramics Research Center and has taught as Baltimore Clayworks and the Wayne Art Center. His favorite pattern is paisley or argyle and his artwork presents viewers with a bridge between design and abstraction. His inspiration comes from the binary between early and contemporary minimalism, design and free will, and also Ruskin and Morris. His artwork and other projects are available here. Jeremy Sims was born in Flower Mound, Texas but doesn't live there anymore. Past Exhibitions:March 2018: A Home is What is Home
Description:
Jeremy Sims is an artist, collaborator and educator making work in Philadelphia. He is the Program Coordinator at University City Arts League and in the past has worked with various projects and collectives such as Nobody's Gallery and The Art Locker. In 2012 Jeremy was a resident artist at the Guldagergaard International Ceramics Research Center and has taught as Baltimore Clayworks and the Wayne Art Center. His favorite pattern is paisley or argyle and his artwork presents viewers with a bridge between design and abstraction. His inspiration comes from the binary between early and contemporary minimalism, design and free will, and also Ruskin and Morris. His artwork and other projects are available here. Jeremy Sims was born in Flower Mound, Texas but doesn't live there anymore.

 

Past Exhibitions:

March 2018: A Home is What is Home

Full Page Text: Em Jensen View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-1e651461498d56a3d142 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-1e651461498d56a3d142 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } www.emjensen.net Em Jensen is an artist and poet in Philadelphia. Working primarily in video, performance, and sculpture, her work explores the many uses of comedy and satire.A majority of her work parodies personas of early/mid 2000s reality television. She is interested in how the language of performance and imitative comedy adds a layer of simulation to the already questionable media she appropriates.Em usually eats dinner at 10 pm and received her BFA from Moore College of Art Design in 2017.
Description:
Em Jensen is an artist and poet in Philadelphia. Working primarily in video, performance, and sculpture, her work explores the many uses of comedy and satire.

A majority of her work parodies personas of early/mid 2000s reality television. She is interested in how the language of performance and imitative comedy adds a layer of simulation to the already questionable media she appropriates.

Em usually eats dinner at 10 pm and received her BFA from Moore College of Art Design in 2017.

Full Page Text: Alyssa Kreilick is an artist whose work includes ideas about the relationship between the artist, the viewer, and the space where art happens.  Her personal and curatorial practice explores questions of imagination informing reality, and the other way around.  Images of the natural world are often involved as a starting point for these ideas.  Currently, Alyssa works in the field of historic preservation and as an illustrator with Morning Circle Media, a local bilingual children's book company.        Past Exhibitions: ovember 2017  Natural Phenomena December 2017 Frito Bastien: Solo Exhibition
Description: December 2017 Frito Bastien: Solo Exhibition

Full Page Text: Will Owen View fullsize View fullsize #block-6703a87a00022e6e69cf .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-6703a87a00022e6e69cf .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } Will Owen is an artist working primarily with design, interactive media, sound, and food. Originally from western North Carolina and currently based in both Philadelphia and Queens, NY, Will is interested in the social intersections of the organic & synthetic, memory & perceived reality, and Fozzie Bear & Miss Piggy. Will is currently an artist in resident at Flux Factory in Queens, New York. Will has exhibited domestically at such institutions as: the original site of the Black Mountain College, Museum of the Moving Image, Center for Performance Research, and Philadelphia Water Works Museum. He has exhibited internationally in Wales, Denmark (notably at ARoS Museum and Kunsthal Aarhus), Russia (Museum of Soviet Arcades), and Iceland. Will  was included in a 2014 Harvard peer-reviewed study of the "most memorable data visualizations" regarding his design work for the international medical humanitarian aid organization Doctors Without Borders.Past Curatorial / Exhibition Work at Little Berlin & The Annex:July 2014: Between The Act And Motion: Little Berlin at Artscape in BaltimoreAugust 2014: Kevin McNamee-Tweed: Books August 2014: Three Truths and a Lie: A Night of Short FilmsSeptember 2014: Zodiac Dinner Club PhiladelphiaNovember 2015: Pivot: Consuming | SubsumingApril 2016: Jet Lag: Solo Works by Julie BitschSeptember 2016: VillusJuly 2017: ReuptakeAs ArtistNovember 2014: Hard to PleaseNovember 2014: The Floral Kombat FINISH THEM! Dinner PartyApril 2017: Found
Description:
Will Owen is an artist working primarily with design, interactive media, sound, and food. Originally from western North Carolina and currently based in both Philadelphia and Queens, NY, Will is interested in the social intersections of the organic & synthetic, memory & perceived reality, and Fozzie Bear & Miss Piggy. Will is currently an artist in resident at Flux Factory in Queens, New York. Will has exhibited domestically at such institutions as: the original site of the Black Mountain College, Museum of the Moving Image, Center for Performance Research, and Philadelphia Water Works Museum. He has exhibited internationally in Wales, Denmark (notably at ARoS Museum and Kunsthal Aarhus), Russia (Museum of Soviet Arcades), and Iceland. Will  was included in a 2014 Harvard peer-reviewed study of the "most memorable data visualizations" regarding his design work for the international medical humanitarian aid organization Doctors Without Borders.

Past Curatorial / Exhibition Work at Little Berlin & The Annex:

August 2014: Kevin McNamee-Tweed: Books

Full Page Text:
AMALIA WIATR LEWIS

 

 

Amalia Wiatr Lewis is an interdisciplinary dance artist. Her dance work asks questions of space, time, and relationships through the exploration of idiosyncratic gesture, somatic practices, and improvisational scores. Her current movement practice uses abstract experiments to explore ideas of domesticity, gender politics, internal psyches, and the self and the other.

 She also makes functional ceramics and sometimes photographs the funny aspects of our built environment.

 

Past Curatorial / Exhibition Work at Little Berlin & The Annex:

January / February 2017: Member Exhibition 2017
September 2017: Now then,

MARY HENJES View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-5d95443680aa55ffc30a .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-5d95443680aa55ffc30a .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } Mary Henjes is a sculptor, writer, and installation artist living and working in Philadelphia. Through the use of material language and dialogue, her work explores ruminations, failures, and shift spaces within topics of memory, home, space, mourning, intimacy, future forms and desires, and the queering of all of the aforementioned topics. Henjes received a BA from Bard College in 2017. cargocollective.com/mhenjes
Description:
Mary Henjes is a sculptor, writer, and installation artist living and working in Philadelphia. Through the use of material language and dialogue, her work explores ruminations, failures, and shift spaces within topics of memory, home, space, mourning, intimacy, future forms and desires, and the queering of all of the aforementioned topics. Henjes received a BA from Bard College in 2017.

 

cargocollective.com/mhenjes

Full Page Text: Terrill Warrenburg View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-f32775aef79bf76cb33f .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-f32775aef79bf76cb33f .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } www.terrillwarrenburg.comTerrill Warrenburg is an interdisciplinary artist, independent curator, and graphic designer living in Philadelphia.  Terrill is interested in incorporating as many mistakes as possible into her artistic practice. Exploring the relationship between digital manipulation and delicate, yet deliberate, hand drawn mark-making, Terrill never considers her work complete and returns to her “paintings” at any time. Terrill's curatorial interests include collaborative partnerships, cross-cultural dialog, alternative media, and art's ability to foster empathy between individuals.  Terrill's curated exhibitions at Little Berlin include:Transplant (July 2018)Homecoming (May - June 2018)EST & UTC +5 (January 2018)FOUND (April 2017)Member's Exhibition (Jan - Feb 2017)
Description:
Terrill Warrenburg is an interdisciplinary artist, independent curator, and graphic designer living in Philadelphia.  Terrill is interested in incorporating as many mistakes as possible into her artistic practice. Exploring the relationship between digital manipulation and delicate, yet deliberate, hand drawn mark-making, Terrill never considers her work complete and returns to her “paintings” at any time. 

Terrill's curatorial interests include collaborative partnerships, cross-cultural dialog, alternative media, and art's ability to foster empathy between individuals. 

 

Terrill's curated exhibitions at Little Berlin include:

Transplant (July 2018)

Homecoming (May - June 2018)

EST & UTC +5 (January 2018)

FOUND (April 2017)

Member's Exhibition (Jan - Feb 2017)

Full Page Text: Eric Anthony Berdis View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-e70c7b5bc3da8684a4c9 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-e70c7b5bc3da8684a4c9 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } Eric makes work that presents alternative realities that subverts the body, materials and conventions of video and performance as way to contextualize a specific moment. Questioning ideas around “otherness”, binary systems, power and subversion through performance both live and on camera. They use absurdity and pathos to create new mythologies that explore idolatry and fandom while embracing everything perverse.  Eric is currently the Zine Librarian at Little Berlin.  He is interested in supporting the DIY-culture that intersect around theory of Gender and Sexuality.  Originally from Erie, Pennsylvania, they received their BFA from Slippery Rock University. In 2016, they completed a post baccalaureate program with the Fibers & Material Studies Department at Tyler School of Art.  Website: http://cargocollective.com/ericanthonyberdis Past Exhibitions:June 2017: I Grit My Teeth Before It BeginsJune 2017: Bedside Manner Zine Release
Description:
Eric makes work that presents alternative realities that subverts the body, materials and conventions of video and performance as way to contextualize a specific moment. Questioning ideas around “otherness”, binary systems, power and subversion through performance both live and on camera. They use absurdity and pathos to create new mythologies that explore idolatry and fandom while embracing everything perverse.  

Eric is currently the Zine Librarian at Little Berlin.  He is interested in supporting the DIY-culture that intersect around theory of Gender and Sexuality.  Originally from Erie, Pennsylvania, they received their BFA from Slippery Rock University. In 2016, they completed a post baccalaureate program with the Fibers & Material Studies Department at Tyler School of Art. 

 

Website: http://cargocollective.com/ericanthonyberdis

 

Past Exhibitions:

June 2017: I Grit My Teeth Before It Begins
June 2017: Bedside Manner Zine Release

Full Page Text: Ethan PATRICK Sherman View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-d9894676c6149aae1502 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-d9894676c6149aae1502 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } http://www.ethanpatricksherman.com/Ethan Patrick Sherman makes work in a variety of mediums including painting, photography, sculpture and artist books. By drawing correlations between ideologies of image making and the psychological construction of the meanings assigned to them, he explores ideas that pre-exist in our environment as emotive information to be recorded. Challenging the stability of memories, his work questions what exactly makes us recall a moment, sensation, sight or place. Past Curatorial / Exhibition Work at Little Berlin:June 2016: DeveloperJuly 2017: Uline OfficialAugust 2017: Lógos
Description:
http://www.ethanpatricksherman.com/

Ethan Patrick Sherman makes work in a variety of mediums including painting, photography, sculpture and artist books. By drawing correlations between ideologies of image making and the psychological construction of the meanings assigned to them, he explores ideas that pre-exist in our environment as emotive information to be recorded. Challenging the stability of memories, his work questions what exactly makes us recall a moment, sensation, sight or place.

Full Page Text:
PAIGE FETCHEN

Paige Fetchen received her BFA in Fibers from the University of the Arts in Philadelphia.   In 2011, Paige accepted the Textile Artist in Residence position at Lillstreet Art Center in Chicago.  During her time in Chicago, Paige spent time as a textile designer as well as an educator teaching courses in a variety of textile based practices for numerous organizations and schools.  In 2015, Paige returned to Philadelphia as part of the production staff at the Fabric Workshop and Museum.  In addition to her position at FWM, she maintains a full time studio practice working across a wide array of media from sculpture to traditional textile methods.   Paige currently teaches in the Fibers Department at Tyler School of Art and University of the Arts.

Eric Preisendanz is a curator, art consultant, artist and advisor in Philadelphia. His company, Revolvd LLC, designs custom large format temporary exhibitions for non-traditional clients with venues in Philadelphia.  He serves as a creative advisor on the board of Renegade Theatre Company, and is on the Alumni Board for his alma mater, The University of the Arts, where he earned his BFA in Sculpture in 2010. Eric joined Little Berlin in November 0f 2015. 

 

www.revolvd.com

www.littleberlin.org

www.uarts.edu

www.therenegadecompany.org

REBEKAH FLAKE View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-253f0f107c228aef7a05 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-253f0f107c228aef7a05 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } www.rebekahflake.comRebekah Flake uses visual arts and curation to investigate nostalgia and tourism at sites where national identities are exhibited in contemporary culture. Her interdisciplinary practice is based in Philadelphia: the location of the Declaration of Independence and the political birthplace of the American Revolution. She grew up in Mississippi, which has had its own struggle with national definitions. She is specifically interested in places contained within the political boundary of a nation or city. Through documentary and research-based work, she speaks to the intersection of social history and phenomenological experience at play between the material world and personal identifications with place. In her current body of work, called Niagara Files, she creates images and programming to promote reflection on citizenship in North America. The narrative centers on her claiming Canadian citizenship on the basis of her mother’s birth in British Columbia; however, the project is simultaneously a reflection on the history of migration and settlement on our continent and the extent to which all North Americans can relate to some version of a migration narrative.She received an MFA in 2014 from Tyler School of Art and an MA in 2009 from the Williams College Graduate Program in the History of Art.  PROJECTS AT LITTLE BERLINSWING STATE Magali Duzant: A Means to MeasureUnusually HumanOffice Hours with Suzanne Seesman
Description:
www.rebekahflake.com

Rebekah Flake uses visual arts and curation to investigate nostalgia and tourism at sites where national identities are exhibited in contemporary culture. Her interdisciplinary practice is based in Philadelphia: the location of the Declaration of Independence and the political birthplace of the American Revolution. She grew up in Mississippi, which has had its own struggle with national definitions. She is specifically interested in places contained within the political boundary of a nation or city. 

Through documentary and research-based work, she speaks to the intersection of social history and phenomenological experience at play between the material world and personal identifications with place. In her current body of work, called Niagara Files, she creates images and programming to promote reflection on citizenship in North America. The narrative centers on her claiming Canadian citizenship on the basis of her mother’s birth in British Columbia; however, the project is simultaneously a reflection on the history of migration and settlement on our continent and the extent to which all North Americans can relate to some version of a migration narrative.

She received an MFA in 2014 from Tyler School of Art and an MA in 2009 from the Williams College Graduate Program in the History of Art.

 

PROJECTS AT LITTLE BERLIN

SWING STATE 

Magali Duzant: A Means to Measure

Unusually Human

Office Hours with Suzanne Seesman

Full Page Text: Luke Leyden View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-fee731a2250953f2b279 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-fee731a2250953f2b279 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } http://lukeleyden.com/Luke Leyden graduated from Rowan University in 2010 with a BFA in photography and printmaking. He works in a number of mediums including photography, digital media, and sculpture. His work focuses on an exploration of ones self and ones environment. Based in Philadelphia he has been heavily influenced by the urban environment and has been exploring the complex relationship between the natural and artificial through photography and sculpture. Since undergrad he has been organizing DIY exhibitions in alternative gallery spaces including cafes, bars, and house venues; mixing medias including 2 and 3 dimensional works, performance, music, and poetry with the hope to encourage the less experienced (or traditionally artistic) to engage with and be inspired by art. As a part of Little Berlin Luke hopes to capture an even wider audience and experiment with multimedia exhibitions.
Description:
http://lukeleyden.com/

Luke Leyden graduated from Rowan University in 2010 with a BFA in photography and printmaking. He works in a number of mediums including photography, digital media, and sculpture. His work focuses on an exploration of ones self and ones environment. Based in Philadelphia he has been heavily influenced by the urban environment and has been exploring the complex relationship between the natural and artificial through photography and sculpture. Since undergrad he has been organizing DIY exhibitions in alternative gallery spaces including cafes, bars, and house venues; mixing medias including 2 and 3 dimensional works, performance, music, and poetry with the hope to encourage the less experienced (or traditionally artistic) to engage with and be inspired by art. As a part of Little Berlin Luke hopes to capture an even wider audience and experiment with multimedia exhibitions.

Full Page Text: Mariana Templin  View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-e81adf9bf30f3efba89a .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-e81adf9bf30f3efba89a .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } http://www.marianatemplin.com/Based in Philadelphia, and largely self-taught, Mariana Templin is a visual artist and performer. Her work makes use of a wide range of media—including oils, embroidery, sand, and even digital experimentation such as short animations and gifs.Her work has been on display across the country, and prominent pieces include a mixed media and digital sculpture housing a hidden projector on display in Philadelphia, and an interpretive illustration commissioned for a nationally aired PBS documentary.Strange and saccharine, her work is informed by the moment when you are both charmed and disquieted by a thing—a process that has always been especially visual for her. This liminal space—where you can’t always tell what you are looking at—is universal. It is at once totally alien, and completely commonplace.Her work seeks to speak to a vast array of audiences, while at once asking them to confront a very personal delight and discomfort. To carve that moment out, and create from it its own world that is both incredibly honest, and essentially subjective.Although she titles her work based on the stories that they present to her, she seeks to create work that is as variable as its audience—to create an experience that appears differently to every viewer. A work that unfolds differently to each viewer—that becomes a stage for endless interpretation, and a mirror for each of our unique narratives.Past Curatorial / Exhibition Work at Little Berlin:August 2015: My Dream House
Description:
http://www.marianatemplin.com/


Based in Philadelphia, and largely self-taught, Mariana Templin is a visual artist and performer. Her work makes use of a wide range of media—including oils, embroidery, sand, and even digital experimentation such as short animations and gifs.

Her work has been on display across the country, and prominent pieces include a mixed media and digital sculpture housing a hidden projector on display in Philadelphia, and an interpretive illustration commissioned for a nationally aired PBS documentary.

Strange and saccharine, her work is informed by the moment when you are both charmed and disquieted by a thing—a process that has always been especially visual for her. This liminal space—where you can’t always tell what you are looking at—is universal. It is at once totally alien, and completely commonplace.

Her work seeks to speak to a vast array of audiences, while at once asking them to confront a very personal delight and discomfort. To carve that moment out, and create from it its own world that is both incredibly honest, and essentially subjective.

Although she titles her work based on the stories that they present to her, she seeks to create work that is as variable as its audience—to create an experience that appears differently to every viewer. A work that unfolds differently to each viewer—that becomes a stage for endless interpretation, and a mirror for each of our unique narratives.

Past Curatorial / Exhibition Work at Little Berlin:

August 2015: My Dream House

maddiehewitt.com

Maddie Hewitt is a visual artist and curator from Philadelphia. Her curatorial projects reveal her preoccupation with omnipresent human desires, disposition, and language in order to understand human interaction and its struggles. Since 2013, she has been a member of Little Berlin curating month-long exhibitions, film screenings, performances, artist critiques, weekend-long festivals, and other public events. Her exhibitions have been featured in The Creators Project at VICE, Art F City, and The St. Claire.

ERIC DANGER CLARK View fullsize View fullsize #block-yui_3_17_2_19_1420596152657_6283 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-yui_3_17_2_19_1420596152657_6283 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } http://ericclarkworks.tumblr.com Reverend Eric Danger Clark is a Philadelphia based installation and performance artist. He received his BFA in Printmaking and Sculpture from Rowan University in 2011 and his MFA from the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in 2013 in performance and sculpture. His work is within a one man religion setting up shrines and rituals that involve the audience asking them to do more than passively accept an environment or situation but be challenged by it and challenge back. He also runs a service to cheaply bring performance art to events. He loves useless objects and futile experiences.Past Curatorial / Exhibition Work at Little Berlin:July 2013: Garbage World 7July 2014: Between The Act And Motion: Little Berlin at Artscape in Baltimore
Description:
http://ericclarkworks.tumblr.com

Reverend Eric Danger Clark is a Philadelphia based installation and performance artist. He received his BFA in Printmaking and Sculpture from Rowan University in 2011 and his MFA from the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in 2013 in performance and sculpture. His work is within a one man religion setting up shrines and rituals that involve the audience asking them to do more than passively accept an environment or situation but be challenged by it and challenge back. He also runs a service to cheaply bring performance art to events. He loves useless objects and futile experiences.

Past Curatorial / Exhibition Work at Little Berlin:

July 2013: Garbage World 7
July 2014: Between The Act And Motion: Little Berlin at Artscape in Baltimore

Description:
Peter Erickson primarily works in arts administration, digital media, and community engagement. He has also worked in animation (.gifs, 3D), film editing, sculpture, installation, creative writing, and he was once an avid painter.

His most recent works have included curating virtual utopias (INTERFACE, REPEAT), participating in weird & fantastic happenings (Homecoming, Between The Act And Motion, Fairgrounds Block Party 2013 & 2014), and performing in / facilitating art wrestling matches (LUCHA LIBRE DEL NOCHE, Fort Thunder Attacks... Again!)

Peter was the Little Berlin Fairgrounds Project Director, where he coordinated with 10-25 volunteers on a weekly basis in 2014, built a partnership with Growing Home to grow real food, and negotiated the transition of property ownership from Viking Mill to BMK Properties (more info here).

Peter has also overseen many administrative, financial, and strategic decisions for Little Berlin.

He currently works for Technical.ly, a news and events network for technology communities in the northeast corridor -- the most notable event series being Philly Tech Week.

http://www.peterherickson.com/

Description:
Lee Tusman received a BA from Brandeis University with a focus on Art and Social Change. Tusman has curated dozens of exhibitions and public projects for a diverse group of universities, galleries, institutions, alternative spaces and public interventions including Riverside Art Museum; UCLA; California State University, Northridge; University of California, Riverside; Division 9 Gallery; Space 1026; Little Berlin; J & J's gas station, and his now-retired mobile Volkswagen Vanagon artspace Vanagallery. He is the Creative Director of Hidden City Philadelphia and works on projects that straddle the intersection of ideas that are socially-based, urban in nature and that combine unconventional practices with contemporary visual arts and internet media.

Full Page Text: Eileen Lillian Doyle View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-d574821605d111e1ab1e .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-d574821605d111e1ab1e .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } http://gertiegarbage.tumblr.comEileen Lillian Doyle is a multidisciplinary artist. In 2009 Eileen founded the Garbage World Performance Series. She has produced performance art events in Philadelphia and Chicago, including two festivals. Her focus at The Annex is: to host touring performance artists, hold a monthly meet-up of a performance art video/book club, and to provide space for dialogue amongst live arts practitioners. On her own, her work focuses on experiences as a cancer survivor and the impact this has on her relationships and identity. Eileen has a BFA from The School of the Art Institute of Chicago and is in the arts administration graduate program at Drexel University. In her spare time, she takes long walks.Past Curatorial / Exhibition Work at Little Berlin:August 2012: HUNG: Little Berlin Members ShowJuly 2013: Garbage World 7: Never Nothing NowJanuary 2014: Little White Cubes: Little Berlin at the DCCAJuly 2014: Between The Act And Motion: Little Berlin at Artscape in Baltimore
Description:
Eileen Lillian Doyle is a multidisciplinary artist. In 2009 Eileen founded the Garbage World Performance Series. She has produced performance art events in Philadelphia and Chicago, including two festivals. Her focus at The Annex is: to host touring performance artists, hold a monthly meet-up of a performance art video/book club, and to provide space for dialogue amongst live arts practitioners. On her own, her work focuses on experiences as a cancer survivor and the impact this has on her relationships and identity. Eileen has a BFA from The School of the Art Institute of Chicago and is in the arts administration graduate program at Drexel University. In her spare time, she takes long walks.

Past Curatorial / Exhibition Work at Little Berlin:

August 2012: HUNG: Little Berlin Members Show
July 2013: Garbage World 7: Never Nothing Now
January 2014: Little White Cubes: Little Berlin at the DCCA
July 2014: Between The Act And Motion: Little Berlin at Artscape in Baltimore

Full Page Text: Tyler Kline View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-7e65d19c733bce48232e .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-7e65d19c733bce48232e .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } Tyler Kline received his BA in Anthropology and Sculpture from Portland State University and a MFA in Installation and Sculpture from The Pennsylvania Academy of The Fine Arts. He has curated shows at: Atlanta’s Moving Spirits Gallery, Portland’s Martial Arts Gallery, Zeitgeist and Disjecta, as well as Philadelphia’s Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts and Little Berlin. A Strong believer in the power of Art to revitalize communities and bring about social change; he is fascinated by playing with the porous boundaries between painting, video, sculpture, performance, and printmaking. Kline’s work at Little Berlin braids Visual Anthropology with cross disciplinary aesthetics, forging bonds to make the future solid enough to Bloom.Tyler has served as Little Berlin’s in-house photographer, documenting the various happenings inside the gallery and arranging it all onto the flickr feed.http://marginal-liminality.tumblr.com/ Past Work at Little BerlinExhibitions Curated:March 2014: The Place of Dead Roads November 2011: The Western Lands October 2010: Cities of The Red Night August 2009: Bone Tails March 2008: These Ghosts That Haunt UsArtwork:April 2013: REPEAT March 2012: Flash Fl00d August 2012: Hung June 2010: Forecast March 2009: Prospects June 2009: Offerings
Description:
Tyler Kline received his BA in Anthropology and Sculpture from Portland State University and a MFA in Installation and Sculpture from The Pennsylvania Academy of The Fine Arts. He has curated shows at: Atlanta’s Moving Spirits Gallery, Portland’s Martial Arts Gallery, Zeitgeist and Disjecta, as well as Philadelphia’s Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts and Little Berlin. A Strong believer in the power of Art to revitalize communities and bring about social change; he is fascinated by playing with the porous boundaries between painting, video, sculpture, performance, and printmaking. Kline’s work at Little Berlin braids Visual Anthropology with cross disciplinary aesthetics, forging bonds to make the future solid enough to Bloom.

Tyler has served as Little Berlin’s in-house photographer, documenting the various happenings inside the gallery and arranging it all onto the flickr feed.

http://marginal-liminality.tumblr.com/

Full Page Text: Marshall James Kavanaugh View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-bda0fe65b26aa6823bf6 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-bda0fe65b26aa6823bf6 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } Marshall James Kavanaugh is a dream laborer of words and various art forms used to create poetic dream spaces for his readership to explore. He has published two collections of short stories and several small chapbooks of travel fiction with the small press A Freedom Books. His writing has been featured in several literary magazines including Apiary, -subtext, the Art Blog, and Philadelphia Inquirer. He has performed and had his work exhibited in the Philadelphia Museum of Art, MoMA PS1, Delaware Center for Contemporary Art, Space 1026, and Vox Populi, as well as other cultural spaces in the area. He is the resident writer of The Dream Oven art salon since 2011 and was an active member of the Philadelphia art collective/gallery, Little Berlin, from 2012-2014.Fire. Sun. Salutation. is James Kavanaugh’s second collection of short stories to be published by A Freedom Books. It is a collection of 9 erotic short stories written between 2011-2014, with a series of poems to the muse offering an umbrella for this canon of surrealist erotica. He currently divides his time between travel and writing a novel titled Pharaoh Quintesential’s Grand Salon, which through a series of vignettes, documents one of the greatest parties to ever take place in the city of Philadelphia. When he is not on the road he usually can be found in the Philadelphia area with his two cats assembling dream catchers or building large TV installations.Websites:http://www.marshalljameskavanaugh.comhttp://thedreamoven.tumblr.com (The Dream Oven)http://majakawanders.tumblr.com (Ma Ja Ka)Past Exhibitions at Little Berlin:January 2012: Plato’s Porno Cave – A Dream SymposiumAugust 2012: HUNG: Little Berlin Members ShowMarch 2013: Plato’s Porno Cave – The New World  October 2013: Limits and Demonstrations: A Lula Chamberlain RetrospectiveJanuary 2014: Little White Cubes: Little Berlin at the Delaware Center for Contemporary ArtsJune-July 2014: Plato’s Porno Cave – The TrialJuly 2014: Between The Act And Motion: Little Berlin at Artscape in BaltimoreSeptember 2014: The Dream Oven: A Retrospective   Books:2015. “Fire. Sun. Salutation.” Short stories by Marshall James Kavanaugh.Published and Hand-bound by A Freedom Books2014. “A Dream Dialectic: The Little Death.” Manifesto by Marshall James Kavanaugh.Published and hand bound by A Freedom Books Productions.2013. “A Dream Dialectic: The New Aesthetic.” Manifesto by Willow Zef and Marshall James Kavanaugh.Published and hand bound by A Freedom Books Productions.2012. “The Sleepers and A Midsummer Day’s Dream.” Short stories by Marshall James Kavanaugh.Published and Hand-bound by Willow Zef at A Freedom Books Productions
Description:
Marshall James Kavanaugh is a dream laborer of words and various art forms used to create poetic dream spaces for his readership to explore. He has published two collections of short stories and several small chapbooks of travel fiction with the small press A Freedom Books. His writing has been featured in several literary magazines including Apiary, -subtext, the Art Blog, and Philadelphia Inquirer. He has performed and had his work exhibited in the Philadelphia Museum of Art, MoMA PS1, Delaware Center for Contemporary Art, Space 1026, and Vox Populi, as well as other cultural spaces in the area. He is the resident writer of The Dream Oven art salon since 2011 and was an active member of the Philadelphia art collective/gallery, Little Berlin, from 2012-2014.

Fire. Sun. Salutation. is James Kavanaugh’s second collection of short stories to be published by A Freedom Books. It is a collection of 9 erotic short stories written between 2011-2014, with a series of poems to the muse offering an umbrella for this canon of surrealist erotica. He currently divides his time between travel and writing a novel titled Pharaoh Quintesential’s Grand Salon, which through a series of vignettes, documents one of the greatest parties to ever take place in the city of Philadelphia. When he is not on the road he usually can be found in the Philadelphia area with his two cats assembling dream catchers or building large TV installations.

Full Page Text: Patrick Koziol View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-71d3f7356162837471ab .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-71d3f7356162837471ab .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } Patrick Koziol received a B.A. in Chemistry from Washington University in St. Louis in 2003 and an M.F.A. from the University in Delaware. His work emphasizes material investigation and experimentation to explore how form is created through repetition and iteration. Examining the aesthetic possibilities of processes such as dripping, seeping, layering, congealing and accumulating, he uses a variety of media to imply loose narratives centered on notions of entropy and its manifestations in contemporary environments. He has a strong interest in artist-run non-profit organizations and how they can create welcoming, exciting, and thought-provoking experiences in their communities. He was involved previously as a volunteer at The Soap Factory in his hometown of Minneapolis. He currently resides in Philadelphia and works in a stone sculpture studio.patrickkoziol.com Past work at Little Berlin:February 2014: Never Like It Is Now November 2013: The Citywide Collections Project September 2013: Some Transliterations
Description:
Patrick Koziol received a B.A. in Chemistry from Washington University in St. Louis in 2003 and an M.F.A. from the University in Delaware. His work emphasizes material investigation and experimentation to explore how form is created through repetition and iteration. Examining the aesthetic possibilities of processes such as dripping, seeping, layering, congealing and accumulating, he uses a variety of media to imply loose narratives centered on notions of entropy and its manifestations in contemporary environments. He has a strong interest in artist-run non-profit organizations and how they can create welcoming, exciting, and thought-provoking experiences in their communities. He was involved previously as a volunteer at The Soap Factory in his hometown of Minneapolis. He currently resides in Philadelphia and works in a stone sculpture studio.

ADAM LOVITZ

 

Adam Lovitz, an artist and resident of Philadelphia, utilizes the solitary act of painting and the collaborative component of performance to nurture daily creativity.  While his paintings and imagery strive to slow down the process of seeing, Adam is interested in a more versatile sensory experience found in performance.  Produced with several other Philly makers, the collective !!!!!!!!!!!KEEP IT UP is a ritual of experimentation, dialogue, and play. Adam attained his BFA from University of Delaware and his MFA from Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts.

http://1thunk2thunk.com/

 

PAST EXHIBITIONS AT LITTLE BERLIN:


May 2013: muddy muddy mud finger

erin bernard View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-09a490c30da635fe11b5 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-09a490c30da635fe11b5 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } Erin Bernard  feels strongly that access matters and that all spaces are museums and galleries if we just treat them as they are. As the founder and chief curator of the Philadelphia Public History Truck, she is exploring one path to dismantling access issues in history museums and cultural spaces. Her work focuses on empowering urban communities to create together and hold conversations involving multiple generations and neighborhood stakeholders. She also is particularly interested in capturing and archiving histories which might not be documented otherwise.As an M.A. public history candidate at Temple University and artist, she is exploring the utility of community curating and the effectiveness of nontraditional museum spaces. Her thesis will be about the aesthetics of public history with case studies of mobile projects, including her own. Her process involves letting questions originate in the community, interpreting oral history in tangible ways, and writing counter-narratives to inform installation and exhibition. She is particularly interested in using maps to present memories in juxtaposition with difficult facts. Her inspirations are Fred Wilson, Theaster Gates, Rebecca Solnit, and Alfredo Jaar.Erin is a thrilled to be a member of Little Berlin and an active part of the Fairgrounds project. She works as the Publicity, Engagement and Outreach Associate of the 45-year-old Painted Bride Art Center in Old City, Philadelphia. In the past, she has taught special education in Bronx, NY and is continuously driven to connect children to the humanities to inspire transformative creation. Erin is a tree-hugging Mom of two who dreams of one day owning goats named Magellan and Molasses.http://phillyhistorytruck.wordpress.com (Philadelphia History Truck)http://www.paintedbride.org (Painted Bride Arts Center) Past work at Little Berlin:April 2014: Manufacturing FireEver never night market
Description:
Erin Bernard  feels strongly that access matters and that all spaces are museums and galleries if we just treat them as they are. As the founder and chief curator of the Philadelphia Public History Truck, she is exploring one path to dismantling access issues in history museums and cultural spaces. Her work focuses on empowering urban communities to create together and hold conversations involving multiple generations and neighborhood stakeholders. She also is particularly interested in capturing and archiving histories which might not be documented otherwise.

As an M.A. public history candidate at Temple University and artist, she is exploring the utility of community curating and the effectiveness of nontraditional museum spaces. Her thesis will be about the aesthetics of public history with case studies of mobile projects, including her own. Her process involves letting questions originate in the community, interpreting oral history in tangible ways, and writing counter-narratives to inform installation and exhibition. She is particularly interested in using maps to present memories in juxtaposition with difficult facts. Her inspirations are Fred Wilson, Theaster Gates, Rebecca Solnit, and Alfredo Jaar.

Erin is a thrilled to be a member of Little Berlin and an active part of the Fairgrounds project. She works as the Publicity, Engagement and Outreach Associate of the 45-year-old Painted Bride Art Center in Old City, Philadelphia. In the past, she has taught special education in Bronx, NY and is continuously driven to connect children to the humanities to inspire transformative creation. Erin is a tree-hugging Mom of two who dreams of one day owning goats named Magellan and Molasses.

http://phillyhistorytruck.wordpress.com (Philadelphia History Truck)
http://www.paintedbride.org (Painted Bride Arts Center)

Alex Walcroft View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-ffbe3c7679fc003b01d1 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-ffbe3c7679fc003b01d1 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } Alex Walcroft is a Philadelphia based multimedia artist. His work explores the constraints of identity, our day-to-day social transactions, and the blurry relationship between storytelling and experience. As a curator at Little Berlin, he sought these themes in the work of fellow Philadelphia artists, and in June of 2013, developed a show called “Gone Shadowing” around the work he found. He received a BFA in Sculpture with a minor in Art History from Tyler School of Art in 2012, and was a Gallery Assistant, then Curatorial Member at Little Berlin from January 2012-December 2013.Past Exhibitions at Little Berlin:March 2012: Flash Fl00dAugust 2012: HUNG: Little Berlin Members ShowJune 2013: Gone ShadowingJuly 2013: Garbage World 7 www.alexwalcroft.com
Description:
Alex Walcroft is a Philadelphia based multimedia artist. His work explores the constraints of identity, our day-to-day social transactions, and the blurry relationship between storytelling and experience. As a curator at Little Berlin, he sought these themes in the work of fellow Philadelphia artists, and in June of 2013, developed a show called “Gone Shadowing” around the work he found. He received a BFA in Sculpture with a minor in Art History from Tyler School of Art in 2012, and was a Gallery Assistant, then Curatorial Member at Little Berlin from January 2012-December 2013.

Full Page Text: Caitlin McCormack View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize View fullsize #block-146fd97dd514a598cb73 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid { margin-right: -10px; } #block-146fd97dd514a598cb73 .sqs-gallery-block-grid .sqs-gallery-design-grid-slide .margin-wrapper { margin-right: 10px; margin-bottom: 10px; } Caitlin McCormack became a member late in the winter of 2012. Although she was only able to sustain her affiliation with the space for just over half-a-year, the experience proved to be fulfilling. She was able to facilitate a screening of One 11 with 103 to celebrate the John Cage Centennial, and to co-organize an outdoor performance featuring the Minor Arcana and several Philadelphia-area poets. She assisted with the development of the Fairgrounds and participated in the 2012 member exhibition, Hung. The efforts put forth by each member in order to support the gallery and all of its enterprises provided her with a greater understanding of how such spaces operate. Her appreciation for similar establishments increased tremendously as a result of her brief alliance with Little Berlin.McCormack is currently working as a fine artist in Philadelphia, utilizing media such as stiffened cotton string resembling bone tissue. She is constantly striving to construct a personal taxonomy through the collation of symbols embedded in esoteric contexts, primarily using skeletal animal forms. She has most recently received representation from Paradigm Gallery + Studio and exhibited work at Select Fair during Art Basel week in Miami.http://www.caitlintmccormack.com/ Past Curatorial / Exhibition Work at Little Berlin:August 2012: HUNG: Little Berlin Members Show
Description:
Caitlin McCormack became a member late in the winter of 2012. Although she was only able to sustain her affiliation with the space for just over half-a-year, the experience proved to be fulfilling. She was able to facilitate a screening of One 11 with 103 to celebrate the John Cage Centennial, and to co-organize an outdoor performance featuring the Minor Arcana and several Philadelphia-area poets. She assisted with the development of the Fairgrounds and participated in the 2012 member exhibition, Hung. The efforts put forth by each member in order to support the gallery and all of its enterprises provided her with a greater understanding of how such spaces operate. Her appreciation for similar establishments increased tremendously as a result of her brief alliance with Little Berlin.

McCormack is currently working as a fine artist in Philadelphia, utilizing media such as stiffened cotton string resembling bone tissue. She is constantly striving to construct a personal taxonomy through the collation of symbols embedded in esoteric contexts, primarily using skeletal animal forms. She has most recently received representation from Paradigm Gallery + Studio and exhibited work at Select Fair during Art Basel week in Miami.

http://www.caitlintmccormack.com/

 

Past Curatorial / Exhibition Work at Little Berlin:

August 2012: HUNG: Little Berlin Members Show

Full Page Text:
ANGELA MCQUILLAN

 

Angela McQuillan received a B.S. in Biology from the University of Texas at Austin in 2004 and a B.F.A. in Painting and Drawing from Tyler School of Art in 2011.  Angela's current body of work consists of mixed-media paintings that focus on biomorphic abstraction and the visual language of living organisms.  Recently she has become increasingly interested in community outreach and development.  Her art practice as a whole is an study of various ways that art and science intersect and inform one another. Her ideas involve experiencing the living world with infinite curiosity and appreciation, while coming up with unique solutions to problems through artistic and scientific investigation. Angela currently works as a scientist at Merck in vaccine manufacturing.

www.angelamcquillan.com

Alana Bograd received a BFA from The School of Visual Arts and an MFA from The Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts with a focus on Studio Art and Painting.
